div.p:
I am equally grateful and surprized at your
all about the bar paper letter which has thus strangely fallen
into your hands and which I should have thought as awkward
sishay as possible to all but the writer and the young person to
whence it was addressed. I suppose my young nephew had given
it to some person who was found as is not uncommon of collecting
the parings of the nails of literary liens. He is just now on duty
at a place called Cappoquin and has had the bad fortune to
be employd employed on some disagreeable severumbus concerning
seag culling of turf attached with the loss of several lives. I under=
stand understand my youngster behaved shadily and with humanity at
the same time but this is a horrid state kind of warfare - As for my
manuscript all there can be said of it is that it was ever
like Mr Pages greyhound "good and fair" but the greyhound
was outrun in Cotswold as Slender informs us and time &
too much writing have reduced my ever current halftext
to such pieds de mouche as I am now forming for the exer
cise exercise of your eyes. I fear my son will not ever have the right
to say his hand has been a fine one for the writers most
military scrawl at present. He has a letter for you when
ever his local situation and duty will permit him the
honor of delivering it.

I am just returned from London where I had the
curiosity to go for the Coronation which was really a
pageant worth going a great way to see. I did not think
there had been quite so much virtue in lace and cloth of

cloth of gold as they displayd on this occasion. I am now
returned to my own humble residence to think over all this
magnificence during my own solitary rides over hill and
dale "between the thorn and the sloe" as our old songs have it.
My welch Handcart has returned not much cured of his concern
but with a good deal more to be conceited of as I am pleased
with the progress he has made in his studies. He goes back
after the holidays - I beg my most respectful compliments
for Mrs. Edgeworth and thanks to her for believing that
whatever you can possibly wish from me within my limited
power is to be had for the asking -
I hope you do not suffer to rest living in your ears
after having so well discharged the pious duty in flow in
your last interesting work - I should long since have thanked
you for the valued present of a copy but that which is not
done when it ought to be done at all as no one knows
better in the evy
than the author of
Tomorrow -
div.closer:
Believe me dear Miss Edgeworth
with the greatest respect & regard
Your most
humble servant
Walter Scott
Abbotsford}
3 August}
